title: Duo Streamers: A Streaming Gesture Recognition Framework
author: Boxuan Zhu (OpenInterX, University of Liverpool), Sicheng Yang (OpenInterX), Zhuo Wang (OpenInterX), Haining Liang (HKUST, Guangzhou), Junxiao Shen (University of Bristol), ...
relevance_why: The proposed streaming gesture recognition framework could inform real-time audio-visual interaction methods in Haohe Liu's research, particularly in multimodal integrations and gesture-based audio manipulation.
background: The paper addresses the challenge of recognizing gestures in real-time on resource-constrained devices without relying on large model architectures.
contribution: This paper introduces the Duo Streamers framework to solve the problem of real-time gesture recognition with minimal computational overhead, achieving significant improvements in efficiency and model size.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically require large models or extensive buffering of input data, resulting in latency.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by employing a lightweight RNN-lite architecture and a three-stage sparse recognition mechanism to minimize redundant computation and enhance speed.

key_innovation: The unique three-stage recognition mechanism that dynamically activates models only when needed, allowing immediate gesture detection and recognition.
real_world_impact: This framework can enhance user interactions in devices like smart home systems and VR applications, where gestures are primary input methods. It can lead to more efficient and responsive gesture-based interfaces.
limitations: There are some challenges related to accurately detecting gesture boundaries and adapting the framework for varying operational conditions.

new_terms.RNN-lite: **RNN-lite** refers to a simplified version of recurrent neural networks that reduces the number of parameters and computation, making it suitable for real-time applications.
new_terms.three-stage sparse recognition mechanism: **Three-stage sparse recognition mechanism** describes an approach that segments recognition tasks into specific stages, minimizing resource use by activating full recognition capabilities only when necessary.

open_sourcing: Upon acceptance, all models, code, and demos will be publicly released.
